description:
Anthocharis cardamines, commonly known as the Orange Tip butterfly, is a species of butterfly belonging to the family Pieridae. It is native to Europe and parts of Asia.

The Orange Tip butterfly is a medium-sized butterfly with distinctive wing markings. The male has bright orange-tipped forewings and white hindwings, while the female has white wings with black-tipped forewings. The underside of the wings is mottled in shades of green and white, providing camouflage when the butterfly is at rest.

The life cycle of the Orange Tip butterfly begins with the female laying her eggs on various plants, such as Cardamine and Nasturtium species. The caterpillars, which are green with a dark stripe along the back, feed on the leaves and flowers of these host plants. After pupation, the adult butterflies emerge, typically between April and June, depending on the region.

This species is known for its role in pollination, as the adult butterflies feed on the nectar of various flowering plants. The Orange Tip butterfly is also an important part of the ecosystem, serving as a food source for predators, such as birds and small mammals.

Due to its distinct appearance and widespread distribution, the Orange Tip butterfly is a popular subject for nature enthusiasts and butterfly enthusiasts alike.
